reviewText:
Edit: Please consider supporting the new Early Access game Primal Carnage: Extinction. This is basically an enhanced version of Primal Carnage. Featuring upgraded graphics, more dinosaurs aswell as new customization for both dinosaurs (skins) and humans (skins & weapons). There are also new game modes.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Primal Carnage[primalcarnage.com] is a fantastic Humans VS Dinos game that either consists of Team Deathmatch or a game mode with objectives. This game doesn't get enough credit for the amazing gameplay it offers.


This game has unique and intense gameplay that is hard to find in games, for example:
Playing as the Dinosaurs feels awesome. Sprinting and stalking through the maps as a raptor makes you feel like a true rogue waiting for the perfect moment to pounce your target and rip them to death only to disappear before the rest of the humans know what happened to their valued team member.


Not just the Raptor, but every dinosaur has unique tactics to ensure your survival.

The Dinosaurs
- As a Dilophosaurus you'll mainly make up for your lack in strength and speed with tactics, sticking with the bigger predators     waiting for the perfect moment to spit your damaging and blinding poison at a human leaving them completely blind and defenseless.

- As a Pteranodon you'll scan the ground for vulnerable prey to lift into the air and release at deadly heights, or above racing rivers.

- Playing the ridiculously intimidating T-Rex or Spinosaurus mostly means offense is the best defense. You can eat humans to regain health and even trample them if they decide to get too close for your liking.

- The Carnotaurus is a big brute with incredible speed and strength, sprinting headfirst into humans and smashing them in all directions with their strong attacks.



Having mentioned that, the humans are definitely no pushover in this game. They might be slower and limited in their vision due to the first-person point of view but each of their classes brings valuable tools to the fight.

The Humans
- The trapper can lock a Raptor, Pteranodon or Dilophosaurus in a net, allowing them to come close and instantly dispatch them with their knife.

- The scientist has a tranquilizer that impairs both the vision and speed of dinosaurs, allowing you (or your team) to escape a T-Rex or catch up to an escaping Raptor.

- The Commando is an assault-type class that uses a grenade launcher to deal massive damage to both big and small targets.

- The Trapper uses a shotgun to easily dispatch of the bigger beasts (if he can get close without being trampled) and flares to blind the Dinosaurs and force them to retreat.

- The Pyromaniac uses a flamethrower to deal heavy over-time damage to dinosaurs aswell as a chainsaw to chop up a slow Dilophosaurus or an inaccurate Raptor.

The elements of surprise, teamwork and variation in classes makes this game a blast to play. This is truly the first (online) game allowing you to play a dinosaur that isn't poorly executed. Everything feels incredibly fluent.


I highly recommend you pick up this game, it's cheap for the (guaranteed!) hours of amazing gameplay you'll have. Playing together with a friend is especially fun as you'll either be:

1. Terrified, because your evil friend is in the dinosaur team following your every move.
2. Evil, because your terrified friend is in the human team and you're following his every move.
3. Overconfident, because nothing beats a good Raptor tag-team.. untill you come across a trapper tag-team.


The developers are still hard at work on implementing the newest patch[primalcarnage.com] that includes more human and dinosaur skins (including a Steam Community trading system), aswell as enhanced graphics and gameplay, overhauled maps and the whole new Horde Mode.

Please show your support for this awesome game. :)

I've had this game for quite a while, and was following it for about a 3-4 months before I bought it.
I have to say, this has likely been the best game I've ever played. What this permanent 1.3 may lack in balance, it heavily compensates for that in how regardless of that, it keeps me entertained for hours on end. It is easily the best shooter I've yet to play, again, both in concept as well as gameplay.

On the gameplay: It isn't the absolute best, yet it still is far better than Extinction. There for one, are actual active TDM and GTTC servers where I get decent ping! Though, certainly there are some things wrong with the game. Some of the little things I don't like, (Which I know won't change.) are: The ptera controls, no more sprint jumping to fly, and the dilo not being able to use its shorter-range spit as well as its longer-range one. I also happen to dislike how much damage the scientist does, but all of these are minor, and the game is still fun.

Though this game has deviated from its original L4D style, it still had me wanting to buy it just for how interesting it seems. I can say with absolute certainty that it was worth it. I waited months and months for 2.0, an update that never came, which happened to be replaced by PC:E, a game of which i'm still trying to figure out whether or not I like.

I still miss Lukewarm Media, and the consoling fact that the game was still updating and going strong.
But alas, I'll just have to watch this game slowly die, which may be months, years maybe. But until that time, I'll keep playing. Been a heck of a few years with this game, love it every time I play it.

Thanks to anyone who actually read this.

reviewText:
Primal Carnage is a Competitive Online Multiplayer Team-Based First Person Shooter based amround the classic battle of humans vs dinosaurs. The game progresses as any other standard team-based multiplayer game, through rounds in which 2 teams compete to have the best end score.

You can choose between a few classes of dinosaurs, each with their own unique size, speeed and strengths (raptors, t-rex, ect.) Or you can play as a human and choose between different classes of characters there as well (soldier, hunter, pyro, ect.).

The graphics are not very polished, the sound is decent though and the servers are reliable. The gameplay works and is addictive. However, since Primal Rage: Extinction released, there's barely anyone on the servers except for some experienced veterens who didn't like the changes with Primal Carnage: Extinction made to the gameplay aesthetics.

Also, consider the newer Primal Carnage: Extinction has been released, the core gameplay is basically more-or-less the same but this game seems highly outdated and the newer one seems much more playable, polished and just more enjoyable as a whole.

Pros  Great concept
Dinosaurs are always fun
2 different perspectives, humans r dinosaurs
Cons  A better, more developed successor has been released
Servers are empty except for a few matches with even fewer players
Graphics and animations are not polished
Environments are underwhelming
Final Thoughts:
No disrespect to the veterens who still love and play the game - however many few that is. I, like you, do not like the roleplay games in Extinction but be that as it may, Team Deathmatch in Extinction is still much more polished and a much better quality experience.

Rating (5.5 out of 10)

reviewText:
Primal Carnage is a game like TF2. It requires teamwork, and it's multiplayer!

There are 2 gamemodes, Team Deathmatch, and Get to the Chopper. Team Deathmatch is pretty self-explanatory, and Get to the Chopper is where the humans are trying to capture objectives to reach a helicopter, while the dinos try to stop them.

Each team has five classes. The Commando has an assault rifle with a grenade launcher. His accuracy is pretty bad, so he's good against large dinos like the T-rex.

The Trapper has a net gun which can trap raptors, dilos, and pteras. He can then stab them for an insta-kill. The net can also prevent the rex and carno from biting temporarily. He also has 2 pistols to dish out damage.

The Pathfinder has a shotgun which does a lot of damage at close-range, but doesn't do well far away. It also reloads very slowly. He also has flares, which when looked at by a dino, blind them, which helps to protect capture points and repel dinos.

The Scientist is the sniper of the team. She has a sniper rifle for her primary weapon, and a tranquilzer pistol for a secondary. Her sniper rifle is very powerful, killing a raptor in about 2 shots, but shines when used against pterosaurs and rexes. Her tranquilizer darts do small amounts of damage, but reduce stamina and makes the unlucky dino's vision blurry.

The Pyro has his Flamesaw, a combination of a flamethrower and a chainsaw. The flamethrower does a moderate amount of damage, but is automatic (of course) and continually damages dinos, since they're on fire and all. His chainsaw is very strong, but drains ammo very fast and has it's own stamina bar.

Now for the dinos. The Novaraptor is great at stealth, but decimates human teams when in packs. It's primary attack is to claw, and it's roar allows you to bite as fast as you click, but it drains your stamina so you can't jump or sprint. It's secondary attack is to pounce, and if you land on a human, you begin to nom their unfortunate ugly face. If you get shot by another human, however, you fall off. Pouncing also takes about a third of your stamina, so plan carefully!

The Dilophosaurus is like the Nova, as stealth and packs make it very deadly, but it is a lot less agile, and cannot pounce. However, it's bite does damage and poisons the enemy, kind of like the pyro's burn. The dilo can also spit, like in Jurassic Park, and it damages and blinds enemies. It's roar increases the range of your spit, and when you crouch, allows you to aim it better.

The Pteranodon is very unique. It can fly, and it's roar marks the location of enemies nearby you for all the other dinos to see. (It's an eye above their head.) The Ptera can also pick up humans, and drop them to their doom, whether into the sea, off of a cliff, or just from really high up. However, if you are shot while carrying a human, you will drop the human. This means it is relatively hard to pick up humans working together, so try to focus on lone ones. Oh, and you pick them up with your feet.

The Carnotaurus is like a charger in Left 4 Dead. When he runs, he can ram into humans, breaking up groups of them, and his roar reduces his damage output but makes hits give health. He can also bite and use his head like a baseball bat.

Finally, the T-rex/Spinosaurus. The Rex has a ton of health, and is huge. This makes him a big target, but he can't take too much fire. His primary attack is to bite, and you can move his head up and down with set buttons. If he eats a human, he gets some health back, but eating takes a few seconds. If Rexy picks up a lot of speed, he can trample humans as well. His roar gives nearby dinos an adrenaline boost, increasing their health for a bit. The Spinosaurus can only be used in Get To The Chopper. He has more health then the rex, and can smack humans away with his arms, but it takes longer for him to eat his prey.

Well, that's Primal Carnage. There's also free DLC and skin packs, if you're interested in that. Thanks for reading!

A very promising game, extremely well balanced and very fun to play. Multiplayer is divided into classes, 5 human, 5 dinosaurs, and the gameplay is fast, furious and will keep you on your toes regardless of your specie/class.

The maps are cleverly designed, with some being more human friendly, and some more dino friendly. This game will give you the dose of adrenalin you are looking for, and it also manages to be a very tense  gameplay experience, as a human you always feel you are being hunted, and as a dinosaur you feel like you are stalking your prey.

If you have watched the Jurassic park series of films more times than you can count, and you always wondered how it would be like to be a T-Rex, now is your chance. Primal Carnage delivers on both ends, it's fun to play as a dino and as a human.

The Good

-Five classes for each species, each influencing how you play the game
-Get to the choppah mode adds one more dinosaur class (spinosaurus)
-Servers are usually full, and perform well (low lag usually)

The Bad

-Non existing story (some people might be thrown off because of that)
-No single player mode

7.5/10

If you have watched the Jurassic park series of films more times than you can count, and you always wondered how it would be like to be a T-Rex, now is your chance. Primal Carnage delivers on both ends, it's fun to play as a dino and as a human.

The Good

-Five classes for each species, each influencing how you play the game
-Get to the choppah mode adds one more dinosaur class (spinosaurus)
-Servers are usually full, and perform well (low lag usually)

The Bad

-Non existing story (some people might be thrown off because of that)
-No single player mode

7.5/10

Primal Carnage is a fairly simple game: you play as either a dinosaur or a human, and the goal is simply to be on the winning team. Each round can be around 20-30 minutes, and you have to use your skills in order to kill as many enemies as possible. It can be quite fast paced and sometimes stressful, but always fun regardless whether you play as a dinosaur or human.
It's often on sale, and I'd recommend buying it then. The game is good for killing an hour or so of your time, but there really isn't anything more to Primal Carnage other than maiming your opponents and the amount of maps is fairly small, so perhaps it's not a game one should pay full price for (there isn't a lot of content).

Be aware that there often is a significant amount of lag regardless of your ping, and that does take away from the fun. But the lag isn't always there and it's sufferable. All in all, I do recommend this game for people who enjoy dinosaur games and/or first person shooters.

Primal Carnage definitely stands alone -- and ably, at that -- in the world of FPS games. Lukewarm Media's debut comes out of the gates screeching, roaring, and grenade launching as you fight as either an assorted team of humans or an equally varied team of dinosaurs against the opposite team.

Forget the other dinosaur games that came and went -- this is definitely one to have.

Each class, whether human or dinosaur, has its own unique set of skills, abilities, and weaknesses. The Raptor, for example, is your token stealth class -- he's not got a lot of armor or bulk, but he's fast, can pounce in an instant, and leap higher than every other dinosaur. The Commando class, for the humans, is your token heavy class. He's got an assault rifle with a grenade launcher and can melee kill trapped and injured dinosaurs with ease, but with his big gun comes a lot of recoil and relatively low stamina.

It's really worth the asking price, and for such a low amount it really can't be beat. GET IT!

reviewText:
Spent quite a few hours in the game recently and thought Id post my thoughts on the current version (1.3)
While yes it does have issues that are likely to frustrate many players, the overall game and the challenge of it more then make up for those frustrations for me and it is incredibly fun to play and even just to explore all the mechanics of it.
The core issue in the game itself is its balencing. The balencing is unequal between the dinos and humans, and goes against what you would expect. Classes that should do high damage dont, classes that should have low defense have strong, and similar issues along those lines. There are a lot of tricks to get around these problems that you will quickly learn by playing the game on various maps and learning techniques you can use to help overcome the bad balencing.
Otherwise, technically the game runs very well, there are a few of the usual Unreal Engine errors, but certainly nothing game breaking or enjoyment stopping. The game feels VERY smooth to control, and I don't get any motion sickness like I usually do with FPS games, although it is worth noting that setting up a controller is incredibly difficult and not doable from just in game.
So yes while it does have a few issues I find the game itself incredibly enjoyable. The satisfaction of taking out a Rex, or dealing with a bouncy raptor is great, the same as you get as a dino when you manage to sneak up on a human and kill them or set up a run to do mass damage to a group at once. Turning around and seeing a dino charging at you is terrifying, helped by the great sense of scale that the devs have used model wise, and being killed across the map by a human with great aim really keeps you on your toes as a dino.
While its not the most spectaular looking game, the graphics and assets they have used work very well together. Flora moves when you touch it, which means keeping your eyes open is very helpful, and the maps are well spaced, and often have unique balencing across various areas of the map itself. There is also a nice variety of map styles that you can play, if you can find servers using them.
I do highly recommend the game, and it is great deal of fun, although if the balencing is likely to extremely frustrate you, you might be better off waiting for the v2.0 thats being worked on.

reviewText:
primal carnage is a weird game. Some would say it is a terrible game, there is little variety in the human classes and the weapons are uninspired, boring and lack impact. Many of the maps are confusing, clutters of bushes and rocks, lacking any personality or landmarks, making navigation almost impossible. There are barely any servers and the netcode is horrible, making everything delayed due to this awkward lag. The launcher of the game will even sometimes crash and the menus might glitch out sometimes preventing you from joining any games. The community is silent and you barely find anyone talking anywhere, well I should say typing, since the game doesn't have voice chat. However you can communicate with other people with 2 whopping sound clips that make the voice commands in CS:GO and TF2 pale in comparison. The balancing is severely off as well, the dinosaurs being way overpowered compared to humans.

However, the game is riddled with all sorts of problems, sometimes, during a full moon when the stars align, you will not even notice all of this, because you will be having such a great time. playing as the OP dinosaurs is a blast, ramming people as a carno, pouncing as a raptor or eating everyone in your way as a T-rex never gets old. When you do get to be in one of these rare games where everything is just sunshine and lollipops, you realize this game has real potential, but it is just buried under so much filth and just needs polishing to uncover these great bits. Therefore I would give this game a rating of 3/10 and I definitely would not recommend anyone buying this for the 15 euros that it is now. However I will recommend it, since there is a lot of fun to be had here once you get over the initial ♥♥♥♥ factor.

in the end, buy it if it is on a sale, do not buy it for the full price.

reviewText:
Primal Carnage is a game where you either play as human or dinosaur trying to complete different objectives:

Presentation:
Being build in what I assume to be UE4, particles, motion blur, etc. are extremely good. However, I feel like the models could be a bit better. Textures (except for the ground) look really good.

Sound design:
There's not much music in here, but the game sounds extremely good, from amazing shotgun sounds to scientifically accurate dinosaur roars.

Maps:
Maps are absolutely amazing, period.

Gameplay:
You either play as a human in first person, or a dinosaur in third person. Gameplay needs some tweaking. The character with the shotgun is extremely OP along with the pyro, but you'll enjoy the game nonetheless.

Cons:
I initally found this game annoying, but you just have to get into the game before realizing how fun it is. The learning curve is also extremely steep. So I would recommend looking things up

Verdict:
The game is cheap (I even won it for free in a giveaway) and fun, I really recommend this title.

Primal Carnage gets an 8/10

reviewText:
Primal Carnage is a game where you either play as human or dinosaur trying to complete different objectives:

Presentation:
Being build in what I assume to be UE4, particles, motion blur, etc. are extremely good. However, I feel like the models could be a bit better. Textures (except for the ground) look really good.

Sound design:
There's not much music in here, but the game sounds extremely good, from amazing shotgun sounds to scientifically accurate dinosaur roars.

Maps:
Maps are absolutely amazing, period.

Gameplay:
You either play as a human in first person, or a dinosaur in third person. Gameplay needs some tweaking. The character with the shotgun is extremely OP along with the pyro, but you'll enjoy the game nonetheless.

Cons:
I initally found this game annoying, but you just have to get into the game before realizing how fun it is. The learning curve is also extremely steep. So I would recommend looking things up

Verdict:
The game is cheap (I even won it for free in a giveaway) and fun, I really recommend this title.

Primal Carnage gets an 8/10

reviewText:
I'm a avid fan of dinosaurs, have been since preschool honestly. So perhaps my review is a bit bias?? Mayhaps? Welp, I'm not instantly in love with every dino related thing that comes out. There is a lot that can go wrong. so some pros and cons.

Pros:
1) The dinosaurs have skills and powers that fit with what it is. The animation of these is terrific. I'v been charged at when I was a human and punted around. It feels smooth and not wonky and awkward so when your a raptor pouncing on someone there isn't this a awkward glitchy *waiting for animation to line up* thing that you might get from other games. Which makes it feel more epic and fluid. Also, they don't needlessly have guns attached like in other titles since well lets face it they are pretty badass without them.

2) Yeh I like dinosaurs, and I like playing as the dinosaurs but I legitmentally enjoyed playing both sides. I was concerned that I'd be upset at playing the humans because I'd be waiting to switch sides. Not the case at all. It was really thrilling to be running around, hiding and hunting and really fun to try to kill these beasts. The balence is really great and far too often games like this would tip the scale to make the humans stronger to stand a chance but no everything feels accurate.

3) This is sort of a mix of TF2/CSGO/Jurassic Park, I found out about this when I was playing CSGO and had an idea of, 'wouldn't it be great if like the entire Terrorist Side was replaced by Raptors?' And to my delight someone says 'that exists'! If you want to, join or host a server with your friends. Play as all raptors if you wanted.

4) NOMNOMNOM! Pouncing, teamwork and straight up clever girl moments. I <3 it.

Cons:

1) I'v only played about an hour so far but had trouble figureing out some of the controls. My poor little Pteranodon floundered around like a wounded bird for a little while, honestly I expected it to glide. It was still fun, but yeh spend a little bit of time to play with the controls before you judge it. I have a feeling some people just didn't bother to learn before they reviewed. They aren't difficult honestly, just don't expect any tutorials. Also, I'v seen people do things that I can't figure out how to do. Not sure if it is controls related or dlcs.

2) uuuuh... Maybe more dinos? This isn't a con really, there are only 5 but I think a lot can be done and who knows maybe it can but I haven't explored that far. But yeh like host a server and change up what type of dinos are allowed of a like pick 5 from a list of 20. Or even limit it to 1 type. Who knows, maybe future updates but either way awesome the way it is.

3) Would be nice if you could earn skins or gear from in game. Like earn points per kill or even a drop system like csgo. I'm not a huge fan of buying dlc's for that, but I don't feel it is pay to win or anything so I'm putting it as a minor offence.

4) Would love the option to first person as the dinos. 3rd person is nice and all for the epic jumps and animation but still would like to toggle between the two options. Heck they could even use it to nerf a trex by giving it motion based vision.

I'v glanced at some other reviews and not sure why people would not recommend this. So take those with a grain of salt. It's pretty clear about what it is on the tin, so if you aren't into that then well move on.

reviewText: Gameplay is simple, yet deviously fun. A good team can make your enemies scream in rage, and a bad team will lose the match for you, so it is very dependent on good players; however, the way the game is built (horrendously overpowered dinos - a good thing, mind you -, scattered spawn points, and just a lonely time on your own) mean that a team will naturally come together, and few things are more satisfying than the mighty, fearsome, invincible tyrannosaurus stomping on screen, only to be turned into a glorified roast turkey by a hail of bullets and flame. The two game modes, Deathmatch and Get to the Chopper, usually play out very quickly and easily. This is bad and good; it is an incredibly easy game to just jump into, but it's no Battlefield 4 tactically speaking. If you just want to shoot some dinos (or eat some humans) while having wicked, mindless fun, this game is definitely worth the buy.

reviewText:
Cannot recommend any game that gets stuck in a .NET Framework failed installation loop.

For anyone that doesn't know what that is basically the game tells me it needs to install Microsoft .NET Framework version 4.  Unfortunately the install always fails if you have a newer version of the framework (like 4.5) This causes your system to force restart in a minute.  And when windows boots back up, you're greeted with a message... That installation failed again and that your computer is going to reboot in a minute....

To avoid the loop don't click the close button on the error message.  Instead hit Ctrl+Shift+Esc to quickly pull up Task Manager.  under the processes tab find 'Setup.exe' and click on that and then the end process button at the bottom of the window.   Sure you wont be able to play the game because of the failed non-installation of Framework, but now you won't need to go crazy trying to fix your computer either.

Strangely enough if you boot the game directly from your steam folder you avoid this nonsense altogethor and can hop in the game.

reviewText:
Cannot recommend any game that gets stuck in a .NET Framework failed installation loop.

For anyone that doesn't know what that is basically the game tells me it needs to install Microsoft .NET Framework version 4.  Unfortunately the install always fails if you have a newer version of the framework (like 4.5) This causes your system to force restart in a minute.  And when windows boots back up, you're greeted with a message... That installation failed again and that your computer is going to reboot in a minute....

To avoid the loop don't click the close button on the error message.  Instead hit Ctrl+Shift+Esc to quickly pull up Task Manager.  under the processes tab find 'Setup.exe' and click on that and then the end process button at the bottom of the window.   Sure you wont be able to play the game because of the failed non-installation of Framework, but now you won't need to go crazy trying to fix your computer either.

Strangely enough if you boot the game directly from your steam folder you avoid this nonsense altogethor and can hop in the game.

reviewText:
Surpisingly fun, despite the ridiculous concept behind the game.  Its simple, addicting, and entertaining.

The human teams feel like something out of an Alien vs Predator game, with the player never knowing if there's something leaping at him from behind, or scoping them out from above.  And there's always the general feel of hopelessness as you notice a T-Rex coming your way.

The dinosaur teams are entertainingly diverse, with each one serving a purpose.  The Novraptors are entertaining, and feel like the general soldiers of the team, as they're fast, do a lot of damage, and in plenty.  However, flying with the pternadon is a chore with its semi-buggy flying mechanics, and not very rewarding unless you like being helpful to your team, or just enjoy picking people up to drop them from the skybox.  The dilophosaurus are a bit underwhelming as well, being extremely underplayed because their only skills are utility, with their blinding/poison abilities.  And good luck trying to snatch a T-Rex role, but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ does it look ♥♥♥♥ing fun.

All in all, I'm extremely happy with the game, but I have no illusions that is anything but arcadey fun.  Its not deep, and probably won't snag a thousand hours by anything, but it is entertaining, and something to quickly pick up and play.

reviewText:
If the current gaming trend switches from zombies to dinosaurs, I would be overcome with joy – not that I haven’t enjoyed fighting countless hordes of zombies, but dinosaurs are simply awesome. I’ll try and keep the amount of Jurassic Park quotes to a bare minimum for this review, but I make no promises, hold onto your butts.

When the miracles of modern science have brought dinosaurs back to life, a ragtag group of humans have been sent to “The Island” in order to reclaim it after the prehistoric beasts have broken loose. Sound familiar? With no indication on where the island is located, it might as well be called Isla Nublar.

Developed by Lukewarm Media, Primal Carnage provides fast team-based competitive online multiplayer action across a single game mode: Team Deathmatch. Each side – humans or dinosaurs – features five distinct classes, that when used in unison provide the best chance at winning the match.

The humans are played in first-person with each class equipped with a unique primary weapon – along with a secondary ability. The Pathfinder wields a shotgun, but also comes equipped with flares that can blind any nearby dinosaurs. The Trapper focuses on shooting nets, immobilizing the smaller dinos, while the Scientist can deplete the stamina of the larger dinos by firing tranquilizer darts. The Pyromaniac focuses on being a problem to any dinosaur that wants to get up close with a combination flamethrower and chainsaw. Meanwhile, the Commando comes equipped with a heavy machine gun and a grenade launcher – best used to take out the larger dinosaurs.

On the other side, the dinosaurs focus on getting up close and personal with their claws and teeth to rip the humans to shreds.This is in stark contrast to the humans play style of using ranged weapons to their advantage. While the game implies a first-person perspective for the humans, the dinosaurs feature a third person perspective. Feeling more versatile and nimble than the human counterparts, they are able to set traps and ambushes by peering around corners with ease. Novaraptors are at their deadliest when working in packs, ambushing their prey and leaping on their foes back while biting them to death. The Dilophosaurus is a support class, blinding it’s prey with a tar like spit that can also poison, while the Pteranodon can spot enemies for teammates, as well as carry and drop them over the nearest cliff. The two largest dinosaurs in the game – the Carnotaurs – uses it’s unbreakable head as a battering ram that sends humans flying through the air, while the mighty Tyrannosaurus can swallow people whole as well as crush everything beneath their massive feet. Each one also comes with a secondary roar ability, which provide buffs to nearby dinosaurs or like in the case of the raptor, it increases attack speed at the cost of stamina.

As you can see, both sides have unique play styles, yet both sides feel balanced. The class structure was set up so each side has a class better suited against a class on the other side. While Commandos can provide a steady stream of gunfire, the high recoil provides limited accuracy, making them a poor choice at taking down anything but the larger two species of dinos. On the other hand, the Trapper is best suited for trapping the smaller dinosaurs, while the Scientist and her sniper rifle can take down any Pteranodon circling in the air. Don’t expect to survive a one on one with a dinosaur, especially since you never know if one is waiting right around the corner. Clever girl.

Playing as a human, other humans are highlighted on the map allowing you to easily reach them upon respawn in order to have a better chance at survival. Some of the most intense moments I’ve had revolved around trying to reach the safety of inside a complex while trying to outrun a T-Rex. Moral of the story, if the T-Rex spots you, and you are all alone, be prepared to a prehistoric dinner.

Much like myself, everyone wants to play as the dinosaurs. Given everyone an equal chance, each round will flip the sides so everyone will get the chance at playing the hunter and the hunted. While only containing five maps, each one provides detailed landscapes full of lush vegetation, trees, tall grass, bushes and all manners of flora that sway with the breeze – as well when a mighty beast moves through them. Sunlight filters through tall tree branches and leaves, while buildings and other objects provide various levels of vertical terrain, all with impressive looking textures. The night time raining map in the thick jungle provides the most intense time you will have with the game, if you are playing on the human side. The thick foliage and lack of light keeps the tension high and keeps you guessing where the next raptor will jump out from. The dinosaur models and animation in particular stand out as a testament of what a dedicated team can achieve.

None of the visuals would mean a thing, if the game didn’t play well, but the old-school arcade style fits the game beautifully. When servers start to fill out, the action become chaotic with humans trying to stay together in order to survive with the threat of dinosaurs that cane come from any direction.

Simply Put

With no progression system, stat-tracking or leaderboards – as of yet – Primal Carnage lacks features that many modern day games include from the get-go. Primal Carnage is light on features and content, but addicting gameplay provides hours of entertainment and most importantly fun, even if the game only currently has a single game mode. And with Lukewarm Media planning updates that will feature new game modes, maps, skins and more, Primal Carnage has brought dinosaur games back from extinction. Releasing for only $15 on Steam, you won’t have to spare no expense, like our dear friend John Hammond.

Don’t expect to survive a one on one with a dinosaur, especially since you never know if one is waiting right around the corner. Clever girl.

Playing as a human, other humans are highlighted on the map allowing you to easily reach them upon respawn in order to have a better chance at survival. Some of the most intense moments I’ve had revolved around trying to reach the safety of inside a complex while trying to outrun a T-Rex. Moral of the story, if the T-Rex spots you, and you are all alone, be prepared to a prehistoric dinner.

Much like myself, everyone wants to play as the dinosaurs. Given everyone an equal chance, each round will flip the sides so everyone will get the chance at playing the hunter and the hunted. While only containing five maps, each one provides detailed landscapes full of lush vegetation, trees, tall grass, bushes and all manners of flora that sway with the breeze – as well when a mighty beast moves through them. Sunlight filters through tall tree branches and leaves, while buildings and other objects provide various levels of vertical terrain, all with impressive looking textures. The night time raining map in the thick jungle provides the most intense time you will have with the game, if you are playing on the human side. The thick foliage and lack of light keeps the tension high and keeps you guessing where the next raptor will jump out from. The dinosaur models and animation in particular stand out as a testament of what a dedicated team can achieve.

None of the visuals would mean a thing, if the game didn’t play well, but the old-school arcade style fits the game beautifully. When servers start to fill out, the action become chaotic with humans trying to stay together in order to survive with the threat of dinosaurs that cane come from any direction.

Simply Put

With no progression system, stat-tracking or leaderboards – as of yet – Primal Carnage lacks features that many modern day games include from the get-go. Primal Carnage is light on features and content, but addicting gameplay provides hours of entertainment and most importantly fun, even if the game only currently has a single game mode. And with Lukewarm Media planning updates that will feature new game modes, maps, skins and more, Primal Carnage has brought dinosaur games back from extinction. Releasing for only $15 on Steam, you won’t have to spare no expense, like our dear friend John Hammond.
